Program for Economic Research on Regulation
Apr 6

Shoddy Economic Analysis? Tell It to the Judge!

In March, the Mercatus Center released a working paper by Reeve Bull and Jerry Ellig, titled “Judicial Review of Regulatory Impact Analysis: Why Not the Best?”

The paper reviews voluminous case law to make the case that courts could competently review the quality of regulatory agencies’ Regulatory Impact Analyses, without imposing their own policy views, if three statutory reforms were enacted:

1. Specify that a Regulatory Impact Analysis (or any comparable economic analysis accompanying a major regulation, regardless of what it is called) must assess the nature and significance of the problem the regulation seeks to solve, identify alternative possible solutions, and estimate the benefits and costs of the proposed regulation and its alternatives.

2. Clarify the standard of review to ensure that courts scrutinize the evidence on the record to determine whether the agency committed a significant error in its analysis, overlooked relevant evidence, or relied on comparatively weak evidence when more persuasive evidence was available.

3. Allow a court to remand a regulation if an omission or error in the analysis led to a material difference in the regulation.

Ohio State University law professor Chris Walker, writing at the Yale Journal on Regulation’s Notice and Comment blog, promptly urged readers, “Definitely go read the full paper.” We concur!
